reasoning: The critique targets one specific supporting move in the post: the claim that economic estimates of the CES substitution parameter ρ “don’t include smarter/faster workers,” which the author uses to argue ρ should be higher for AI R&D. That point is relevant but not load-bearing, since the post offers many other independent reasons (extrapolation range, long-run adjustment, experiment efficiency, multiple routes, etc.), so centrality is moderate-low. The critique has moderate strength because it correctly notes that in many growth/accounting and production-function contexts, labor is modeled as effective labor units (quality-adjusted), so “smarter workers” can be represented as more L and doesn’t by itself overturn diminishing returns when ρ<0. However, it doesn’t fully defeat the author’s intended point: empirical estimates of ρ may be identified from variation in headcount/hours and capital with imperfect quality adjustment, and extreme capability/speed changes could plausibly change the underlying production process/elasticity rather than merely scale L. The critique is mostly correct but somewhat oversimplifies how empirical ρ estimates treat labor quality and how capability changes might affect the production function. It is clear, focused on a single issue, and contains little to no dead weight. Overall it modestly weakens one argument for raising ρ, but doesn’t seriously threaten the post’s overall conclusion.
title: Effective labor units already capture worker quality in standard economic models
